entry.title: Domain Driven PHP
entry.content:
Domain Driven Design

Domain Driven Design (DDD) is a software philosophy popularized by Eric Evans and his book on the subject. It's a pretty sweet way to approach software and it has gained popularity throughout the software community, but I don't see it in the PHP community as much I would like to. I recently undertook a simple PHP application that could effectively demonstrate the concepts, as well as show how to test drive such an application.

The fishing application I developed was inspired by the principles of DDD and Onion Architecture.

View It On Github

The Application

The focus of this project was not to make a cutting edge console application that forces people to weep tears of joy. The purpose of making this application was to test drive a simple application that has domain and infrastructure layers. You can follow the directions on the github page to get the tests running and test the actual app out.

The actual application file was pretty easy to make after all the code was tested. At such a high level, it made me pretty giddy to see all my well tested components being glued together to form an application. Let's take a quick look at the pieces that make up this machine.

The purpose of making this application was to test drive a simple application that has domain and infrastructure layers.

Domain

The domain of the application is what houses the what of my fishing app. The domain is where the objects that make up the universe of our application live - that is "what is this application about." The main logic of the application lives here. Let's look at the different pieces of the domain layer.

Entities

Entities are the models of our application, and they are concerned with identity. These are the guys that are persisted in a database, and they are concerned with things like primary keys and ids. Take a look at the fish entity used throughout the application: 

 1 <?php
 2 class Fish
 3 {
 4     protected $id;
 5 
 6     public function getId()
 7     {
 8         return $this->id;
 9     }
10 }

The fish entity is our only persisted model. It is the focus of the application. Without a fish, how can we go fishing!?!?

Repositories

Repositories that interact with the database actually belong in the infrastructure layer, but the interfaces for such objects belong in the domain. They are the objects we interact with to query and persist our entities. Let me show you what I mean by showing an example: 

 1 <?php
 2 interface IFishRepository {
 3     function all();
 4 
 5     function fetch($fishId);
 6 
 7     function store(Fish $fish);
 8 
 9     function delete($fishId);
10 }

These abstract interfaces are crucial for unit testing behaviors with stubs and mocks.

Services

Services coordinate various domain objects. The example application has a PondStocker service that is in charge of stocking the Pond object with a given number of fish. The Pond and Fisherman objects are services as well. They coordinate functionality between other domain objects.

The domain layer is composed of entities, repositories, services, and value objects.

Infrastructure

Infrastructure is what makes the application tick. This is where configuration, database objects, and third party libraries live.

Persistence

This namespace is where the implementations of the repositories from the domain live. The fishing application has only one repository implementation, and it is derived from the interface in the domain layer: 

1 <?php
2 class FishRepository implements IFishRepository
3 {
4 	//.....
5 }

Services

Infrastructure services coordinate lower level pieces of the application. For this application, this includes the autoloader and console helpers.

Vendors

The Vendors directory is where third party libraries are stored. The fishing application relies on Doctrine2 for data persistence.

Tests

PHPUnit was used to test drive this app. It makes use of assertions and mocks/stubs to separate unit and integration tests. I would definitely recommend checking out the tests in the repo to get a feel for how its done.

Check It Out!

Go ahead and check out the repository on Github. There are many ways to persue DDD, and it can be a useful design tool in PHP too.

entry.title: Is Agile Dead?
entry.content:
Why Ask?

I recently had the good pleasure of attending The Kalamazoo X Conference. It's a cool little conference designed to give developers and designers a chance to focus on soft skills - that is interacting with people, communicating, standing out, etc..

It was Leon Gersing that had quite a lot to say on the dominant culture's impact on trends. He had a lot of fun stuff to say about tripping on LSD while programming, failing with joy, and determining your end goal - which for many of us is making software. Leon said one thing that struck a chord with me:

Agile is dead.

Coming from a web warrior like Leon, I have to at least consider it.

Why Is It Dead?

Leon made the point that most people doing Agile today are actually doing Waterfall with Agile terms. That is the dominant culture of Waterfall fan boys has assumed Agile, but has really made it something new.

Doing .NET development, I have seen my fair share of psuedo scrummers, and agile wannabes. Or people who just don't care. Hearing that Waterfall statement resonated with me, because I have seen it happen.

The bottom line matters in business, and I think there are many "big business" types that like the idea of agile, but they like the idea of tons of documentation, and tons of process better. I have a hard time saying Agile is dead, because I am on the front lines constantly fighting for more Agile practices. Less process, better developer/customer interaction, and more working software! These are good things!

Less process, better developer/customer interaction, and more working software!

There Is Hope

I refuse to believe Agile is dead. Watching true wizards like Uncle Bob still do their thing is encouraging. It's plain beautiful to hear guys like this talk about code. Take a waltz down to Uncle Bob's Clean Coders site and see how he lives the dream!

I see it all the time where Agile can still be used to meet the end goal of delivering software. Thats what we do. Thats what we should aim to do. The agile manifesto is getting older, but I think it is still relevant:

Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Working software over comprehensive documentation
Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
Responding to change over following a plan

That is, while there is value in the items on
the right, we value the items on the left more.

Conclusion

I hope to see an attitude and environment that brings new life into this manifesto. I don't think Agile is dead, but it is being suffocated.

entry.title: TDD With Mock Objects And PHPUnit
entry.content:
The problem

Test driven development ,or TDD, should be no stranger to many folks out in the code wilds. Writing tests first aids in design as well as quality control. I am always amazed at how my own testing practices evolve.

It wasn't until recently that I discovered the beauty (and common sense) of separating integration tests from unit tests. Yes yes, integration tests often test units too, but the main focus of these tests is to test how your units (you guessed it) integrate with other components (the server, database, services, etc...).

It can be tricky to isolate unit tests away from integration tests when your units are composed of something that is fundamentally useless without one of those components. Imagine a DB object, or a REST client, or a socket. Your unit tests need to test the units at their core, and not how they integrate with other resources. How do you test a unit that has a dependency on a socket object, without having to worry about opening and closing a socket connection every test?

Mock objects as the solution

These bad boys need to be part of every testers toolkit. We are going to use the socket scenario (and yes this is because it has been my most recent use case) to demonstrate how mock objects can be used to make more pure unit tests. Remember the goal is to separate your tests into unit tests and integration tests.

The unit to test

The unit in question is an object that encapsulates executing a socket command. Think command pattern. The language in question today is PHP, but the principle is the same in other environments. In fact it is a principle I use in the .NET realm with C# and Moq. 

 1 <?php
 2 class SocketCommand
 3 {
 4     public function __construct(BinarySocket $socket)
 5     {
 6         $this->socket = $socket;
 7     }
 8 
 9     public function execute($data)
10     {
11         $this->socket->write($data);
12     }
13 }

Take note that our SocketCommand object forms a dependency with the BinarySocket object. Let's take a look at the BinarySocket class. 

 1 <?php
 2 class BinarySocket
 3 {
 4     protected $socket;
 5 
 6     public function __construct($ip,$port)
 7     {
 8         $this->socket = @socket_create(AF_INET,SOCK_STREAM,SOL_TCP);
 9         $connected = @socket_connect($this->socket,$ip,$port);
10         if (!$connected)
11         {
12             throw new Exception(socket_last_error($this->socket));
13         }
14     }
15 
16     public function write($format,$data, $length = 0)
17     {
18         $binary = call_user_func_array('pack',array_merge(array($format),$data));
19         socket_write($this->socket,$binary,$length);
20     }
21 }

As you can see, when a BinarySocket is instantiated, a connection is opened on the given ip and port. This could really slow down our tests if these connections are being opened all over the place.

Using mock objects to test behavior

Rather than creating these socket objects and having connections opened, we will mock the BinarySocket object in order to test its role in the SocketCommand object. As you can see from the SocketCommand code above, the BinarySocket is used within the execute method of the SocketCommand. We need to test this behavior without being concerned with whether the BinarySocket is making a connection or not.

Here is how we are going to set up the SocketCommand test case using PHPUnit: 

 1 <?php
 2 class SocketCommandTest extends PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
 3 {
 4     protected $cmd;
 5     protected $mockSocket;
 6 
 7     public function setUp()
 8     {
 9         $this->mockSocket = $this->getMockBuilder('BinarySocket')
10             ->disableOriginalConstructor()
11             ->getMock();
12 
13         $this->cmd = new SocketCommand($this->mockSocket);
14     }
15 }

Using PHPUnit's mock library, it is easy to setup an object that will meet the requirements of the SocketCommand constructor. In a library like Moq in .NET town, you would be more likely to test an interface instead of a concrete implementation, but PHP offers a little more "flexibility" here.

The mock object has already allowed us to meet the requirements of the SocketCommand constructor. Our mock object is effectively the required BinarySocket; It meets the required BinarySocket interface, and it does not have the added baggage of actually opening a socket connection.

Remember the SocketCommand makes use of the BinarySocket in it's execute method. We want to make sure this is happening, and this is what we are going to test.

Setting expectations

We need to tell our testing framework, that we expect the execute method of our tested unit to call our mock object's write method. Done!

 1 <?php
 2 public function testExecute()
 3 {
 4     $this->mockSocket->expects($this->once())
 5         ->method('write')
 6         ->with($this->stringContains('vc'),
 7                $this->equalTo(array(00,0x01)),
 8                $this->equalTo(6));
 9 
10     $this->cmd->execute();
11 }

Lets break this down.

expects($this->once()): This line tells the test runner to expect that the method we are testing will be called at least once. If it isn't, then an exception is thrown and the test fails.

method('write'): This is the method of the interface our object is mocking that will be called. In this case we are saying the write method of BinarySocket will be called.

with(...): The with method of our mock object allows us to specify what arguments the chosen method will be called with.

Finally, after we set our expectations, we run the method on our unit to test. If that method does not call the mock object's write method in exactly the way we described it, then an exception will be thrown and the test will fail. Here is the complete test case. 

 1 <?php
 2 class SocketCommandTest extends PHPUnit_Framework_TestCase
 3 {
 4     protected $cmd;
 5     protected $mockSocket;
 6 
 7     public function setUp()
 8     {
 9         $this->mockSocket = $this->getMockBuilder('BinarySocket')
10             ->disableOriginalConstructor()
11             ->getMock();
12 
13         $this->cmd = new SocketCommand($this->mockSocket);
14     }
15 
16     public function testExecute()
17     {
18         $this->mockSocket->expects($this->once())
19             ->method('write')
20             ->with($this->stringContains('vc'),
21                    $this->equalTo(array(00,0x01)),
22                    $this->equalTo(6));
23 
24         $this->cmd->execute();
25     }
26 
27 }

Remember the beauty of this is being able to separate unit tests from integration tests. We have made our SocketCommand testable without worrying about socket connections opening. This has the benefit of making our unit tests faster, but also more concerned with the actual business at hand.

Whatever the language, whatever the environment, mock objects are an indispensable tool, if you want to do effective test driven development that won't slow you or your tests down.

entry.title: JavaScript Masterclass With Thomas Fuchs and Amy Hoy: A Review
entry.content:
Recently I had the pleasure of taking the JavaScript Masterclass with noted JavaScript guru Thomas Fuchs and his brilliant accomplice Amy Hoy. The class was taught over 2 days, each day consisting of a four hour session. Eight hours might not sound like a lot, but there was a wealth of information included.

What they covered

For someone who has been doing JavaScript development for a while, this class had quite a bit of refresh material. Don't let that put you off. Amy and Thomas do a great job of shedding new light on the core of JavaScript, and it doesn't hurt to have an expert or two answering questions via video.

The JavaScript language

Thomas and Amy do a good job of explaining JavaScript's "everything is an object" nature, it's object model, and it's nearly functional design.

It wasn't anything terribly new for me, but I did get rocked on a couple things, and it was really great to have an expert walk you through and confirm your assumptions. A classic example of augmenting JavaScript was taught in the class, and it exhibited much of what makes JavaScript so awesome: 

 1 //a real exercise solution I had to cook up to a class assignment:
 2 Function.prototype.cached = function() {
 3   var self = this, cache = {};
 4   return function(args) {
 5     if(args in cache) return cache[args];
 6     return cache[args] = self(args);
 7   };
 8 };
 9 
10 Math.sin = Math.sin.cached();

This tiny example exhibits a lot of what is taught: JavaScript and the prototype, closures, and the functional powers of JavaScript.

In addition to the core features of the language, Thomas and Amy will drive meta programming into your face - and hard at that. You will learn how to use curry powers and call functions dynamically and use the powers of JavaScript reflection. 

1 for(name in people.Names)
2    people['hello' + name] = function(name, msg) {
3        return msg + ' ' + name;
4    }.curry(name);
5 
6 //now use the dynamic meta power!
7 people.helloBrian('You are cool'); // You are cool Brian;

JavaScript Infrastructure

So many of us (myself included) have had a tendency to look at JavaScript as an exception to "real programming". This part of the course is definitely what I needed to hear and see in action. Scripts and their structure tend to be jumbled into disparate massive minified scripts, or no separation at all exists, and you end up with the same massive file for development and production.

Thomas and Amy show you how to drop this nasty habit and organize your scripts into a helpful folder structure like you would with any other program. The focus of the class was on Sprockets, a nice little tool in ruby with a command line script that can be used.

Given this structure:

You can have a script set up like so: 

1 (function(){
2 //= require "models/mymodel"
3 //= require "models/mymodel2"
4 })();

You can then run the sprocketize command like so:

$ sprocketize -I . main.js > main.prod.js

Voila - your scripts are included into the closure above. No more hassle of dealing with one jumbo script. Thomas and Amy show how this is an invaluable tool, and your JavaScript can and should be treated like any other application code.

One thing to note: The class seems to assume use of Sprockets version 1. Sprockets 1 is a bit outdated at this point, but it gives the desired functionality above. For some reason, Sprockets 2 dropped the ability to have require directives inside of a closure - you are now forced to include directives at the top of a script. This makes it less useful in my opinion, and after wrestling with Sprockets 2 for a hot second, I decided to drop it for Sprockets 1. So when you install that bad brotha, make sure you save yourself a headache:

$ gem install --remote sprockets -v 1.0.2

Unit testing

I'm no stranger to unit testing, but I'll confess it is absent from my JavaScript more often than it should be. Thomas gives a real solid introduction to unit testing in JavaScript, and you will see things you should be used to in your day to day code adventures:

1 //a style you might pick up from the class
2 testSomeUnnamedFactoryFunction:function() {
3     this.assertUndefined($());
4 
5     this.assertNull(document.getElementById('doesNotExist'));
6 
7     //more asserts....
8 }

How they covered it

The class was very interactive. I was able to see Amy or Thomas via video, and they were constantly reading chat and answering questions. They even gave some homework and super fun assignments to tackle - all with feedback. They offered up expert advice, and if you are a beginner you won't be after this class, and if you are in the advanced camp it will definitely confirm your assumptions and even drop a few new goodies your way. It can't hurt to have on your resume that you studied at the feet of the masters either.

Plus, you get the tasty ebook JavaScript Performance Rocks by these two wizards.

The class was also a ton of fun:

I give this course an 11 out of 3!

entry.title: My First Crack At Managing Time With the Pomodoro Technique
entry.content:
Who doesn't struggle with time management? I think that it is a pretty common battle, especially for us developers out there. Every day is tackled with the best of intentions: I am going to learn this, I am going to program that, I am going to blog about this, etc...

The problem is that our focus is very fractured this way. When you set out to do something with no real goal in mind, you tend to set out with very little focus. As each day comes to a close, time becomes the enemy because there is just never enough of it.

For me, the way to remedy the situation is to throw software at it. Set up massive projects with milestones, tasks, and timers that you can click stop and start on. This is good to see what is on the table, but this can be a little daunting, and it still doesn't address the core issue.

The difficulty stems from the fact that we as human beings are quick to go down rabbit holes. Our minds wander. I can't even think of how many times I have sat down ready to read, program, blog, and have just wandered off into something completely different than what I originally intended to do.

An honest look at my typical approach

This is probably a little more honest than most of us young professionals care to be, but this is how a typical task for me goes:

  1. Sit down to work
  2. Open up my text editor
  3. Open up last.fm and start searching for some music I want to listen to
  4. Start writing some code
  5. Don't like the song that is playing so I need to flip through several to get to one I like
  6. Start writing some code again
  7. Been a while since I checked Facebook and Twitter....better do that
  8. Code a little more
  9. Remember that other cool thing I started earlier in the week and revisit that
  10. Email notification pops up so I better read that
  11. Code a little more
  12. Favorite TV show is on...so I have to watch that
  13. Call it a night and go to bed

Well that's embarrassing.... not really a whole lot of actual work getting done.

Pomodoro Technique to the rescue!

The Pomodoro (that is Italian for tomato btw) Technique is a technique that was invented by Francesco Cirillo. The tagline from the book Pomodoro Technique Illustrated by Staffan Nteberg says it all: "The easy way to do more in less time." I had my first crash course in this today with my good friend Bryce Darling. I am still new to it, but here is what I have taken away from it:

Create an "Activity Inventory"

Make a list of what needs to be done. It does not have to be that complicated - think about what needs to be done and write it down (yes on a piece of paper).

Create a "To Do Today" list

Take some items you feel confident about doing off of your activity inventory, and make a list out of them. These should be items you feel confident about completing for the day.

Set a timer and go!

Set a timer for 25 minutes. Work while the timer is ticking down. Ignore those emails, texts, the playlist, that tv show.... and just work. When the timer beeps, take a break!

Today was my first time taking a stab at this, but I was immediately surprised by how productive I was. I was able to complete two page designs in Photoshop in 4 Pomodori (that is 4 25 minute sprints of work). This is possible because the time is extremely focused.

While that timer is ticking, you aren't doing anything but working. When the timer is up, you reward yourself with 5, 10, or 15 minutes of a break. Use that time to check the emails, or set up the playlist. Detach yourself from the work completely. Don't think about what you just did, or what you are going to do next. Just relax.

What I took away from it

I will definitely be reading more from Pomodoro Technique Illustrated, but I see some immediate benefits.

1. Increased productivity.

I saw this evidenced today. I was amazed by how much I was able to get done in such a short period of time.

2. Less anxiety.

By detaching and taking a break for a little bit after each Pomodori, you will decrease your anxiety about the work at hand, and give your brain a chance to run some background threads on what it just did while you sip a coffee, call a friend, or just hang out.

3. Ability to assess what you have done.

It was nice being able to log 75 minutes for a task. This gave me a greater sense of how much time it actually takes to do work. This will have an immense pay off in estimating and boxing off time in the future.

There is still a lot to learn, but so far I am sold on this amazing technique for managing time and getting work done!

entry.title: Mastering The State Pattern In C#
entry.content:
I have been spending a lot of time with my nose in the book Applying Domain-Driven Design and Patterns With Examples in C# and .NET. This is a book with a strong emphasis on design. Period. Design patterns are a big emphasis in this book. I like to think I have a solid grasp of design patterns, but we never know quite as much as we think right? I encountered the classic state pattern and decided to play around with it a bit - that is try it out in a real world situation I encountered recently.

State Pattern Basics

The state pattern exists to easily manage state. Think of state as the difference between on and off. When a light switch is flipped up, then it's state is currently "on". When the switch is flipped down, the state is currently "off". This is a simple case. You could easily have more than just two states. Think of a fancy dimmer! As you turn it, it is 30% brighter, 40% brighter, 60% brighter, etc. Enough metaphor! What does this mean in code town?

The state pattern is composed of two base objects: a context and a state. All states are derived from the base state. The context is the main player - the object that users are really interested in. It is composed of a state object, and has a Request method. The Request method essentially hands off responsibility to the state's Handle method, and the state is responsible for performing the guts of the work and changing the state reference that belongs to the context. For you UML buffs out there, it might look something like this:

Let's take a look at this in code.

The State

 1 namespace StatePattern
 2 {
 3     public abstract class State
 4     {
 5         public abstract void Handle(Context context);
 6     }
 7 
 8     public class ConcreteStateA : State
 9     {
10         public override void Handle(Context context)
11         {
12             Console.WriteLine("Hello from ConcreteStateA");
13             context.state = new ConcreteStateB();
14         }
15     }
16 
17     public class ConcreteStateB : State
18     {
19         public override void Handle(Context context)
20         {
21             Console.WriteLine("Hello from ConcreteStateB");
22         }
23     }
24 }

Here we have our abstract State object that serves as the base for all other states, and a couple of concrete implementations of the base class.

Take a look at ConcreteStateA. Notice that the Handle method accepts a reference to the Context object. Within the method, ConcreteStateA changes the state of the Context object to a different state. This is usually done in response to some condition - for example when an account balance drops below a certain amount.

Let's see how the Context implements the State objects.

The Context

 1 namespace StatePattern
 2     public class Context
 3     {
 4         public State state {get;set;}
 5         
 6         public Context()
 7         {
 8             //the default state
 9             state = new ConcreteStateA();
10         }
11         
12         public void Request()
13         {
14             state.Handle(this);
15         }
16     }
17 }

Here you can see how the Context holds on to a State object. We create a state property and set the default state in the constructor to an instance of ConcreateStateA. Notice that when the Request method is called, the Context passes a reference of itself to the Handle method of the State object. Run this bad boy and you will notice how the State objects take over managing the active state:

1 void Main()
2 {
3     var ctxt = new Context();
4     ctxt.Request(); //Hello from ConcreteStateA
5     ctxt.Request(); //Hello from ConcreteStateB
6 }

A Real World Example

Given a basic understanding of what the state pattern is, it is easy to see how it can be applied to a ton of different scenarios. A little while ago I was charged with managing reward point levels for a customer rewards program. When a customer reaches x amount of total points, they get y level. This problem is just begging to use the state pattern. Let's translate what we learned above into some real world code.

The State

Our state objects will be represented as RewardLevel objects. As a customer accumulates points, they earn new levels or "states" representing their reward levels. So let's translate our state over to a reward level object:

 1 namespace RewardLevels
 2 {
 3     //the interface of our "state" objects
 4     public interface IRewardLevel
 5     {
 6         //Participant is the Context
 7         Participant Participant { get; set; }
 8 
 9         void AddPoints(int points);
10         void SetPoints(int points);
11     }
12 
13     public abstract class RewardLevel : IRewardLevel
14     {
15         public Participant Participant { get; set; }
16 
17         protected int minimumPoints;
18         protected int maximumPoints;
19 
20         public void AddPoints(int points)
21         {
22             Participant.Points += points;
23             CheckState();
24         }
25 
26         public void SetPoints(int points)
27         {
28             Participant.Points = points;
29             CheckState();
30         }
31 
32         protected void CheckState()
33         {
34             var p = Participant.Points;
35             if (p >= 0 && p < 26)
36                 Participant.RewardLevel = new BronzeLevel(Participant);
37             else if (p > 25 && p < 51)
38                 Participant.RewardLevel = new SilverLevel(Participant);
39             else if (p > 50 && p < 101)
40                 Participant.RewardLevel = new GoldLevel(Participant);
41             else if (p > 100)
42                 Participant.RewardLevel = new PlatinumLevel(Participant);
43         }
44     }
45 }

Notice the RewardLevel class creates the basic operations of our custom state. Pay special attention to the CheckState method. This method is fired after any method that changes the state (i.e. changing the number of points). This guy is one stop shopping for updating the RewardLevel state that belongs to the Participant context. Let's look at the following concrete implementations of the RewardLevel class.

 1 namespace RewardLevels
 2 {
 3     public class BronzeLevel : RewardLevel
 4     {
 5         public BronzeLevel(Participant p)
 6         {
 7             Participant = p;
 8         }
 9     }
10 
11     public class SilverLevel : RewardLevel
12     {
13         public SilverLevel(Participant p)
14         {
15             Participant = p;
16         }
17     }
18 
19     public class GoldLevel : RewardLevel
20     {
21         public GoldLevel(Participant p)
22         {
23             Participant = p;
24         }
25     }
26 
27     public class PlatinumLevel : RewardLevel
28     {
29         public PlatinumLevel(Participant p)
30         {
31             Participant = p;
32         }
33     }
34 }

The real beauty of the pattern shines when you implement behavior that is different on a reward level by reward level basis. Maybe you have a method like GetDiscountAmount that returns a higher percent as you get higher in the reward level chain.

The Context

Remember the context is the main object that people are interested in. In this case it is the participant in the rewards program. We are only concerned with what level the participant is, and we only want to interact with that participant.

 1 namespace RewardLevels
 2 {
 3     public class Participant
 4     {
 5         public string Name { get; set; }
 6 
 7         public int Points { get; set; }
 8 
 9         public RewardLevel RewardLevel { get; set; }
10 
11         public Participant(string name, int points)
12         {
13             Name = name;
14             Points = points;
15             RewardLevel = new BronzeLevel(this);
16             RewardLevel.SetPoints(points);
17         }
18 
19         public void AddPoints(int points)
20         {
21             RewardLevel.AddPoints(points);
22         }
23 
24         public void SetPoints(int points)
25         {
26             RewardLevel.SetPoints(points);
27         }
28     }
29 }

Notice how we default our Participant to BronzeLevel in the constructor. We call RewardLevel.SetPoints(points) to update the level to the appropriate level should it be higher than bronze (maybe the points passed in the constructor are coming from a database or being persisted elsewhere).

Notice how our AddPoints and SetPoints methods are calling the same methods on the RewardLevel object. Remember that GetDiscount method we mentioned above? Seeing how we only want to interact with our Participant object, we could easily modify our Participant object to include the following method:

1 public double GetDiscount(int points)
2 {
3     return RewardLevel.GetDiscount();
4 }

Wrapping It All Up

entry.title: Base Pages, Master Pages, and Themes
entry.content:
One aspect of ASP.NET is the concept of master pages and themes. These are two tools that are indispensable when it comes to creating a consistent look and feel for your web application. The concept of a base page will illustrate creating a consistent Page class for all of your web forms to inherit from. Let's do this!

Please feel free to download the source to get a more in depth look at the code and styles used.

Download Source

Creating Consistent Functionality With Base Pages

An important concept in any object oriented language is inheritance. C# is no exception. If you have been hackin away at some web forms lately, you should probably notice that all of your code-behind files have classes that extend the System.Web.UI.Page class.

 1 using System;
 2 using System.Collections.Generic;
 3 using System.Linq;
 4 using System.Web;
 5 using System.Web.UI;
 6 using System.Web.UI.WebControls;
 7 
 8 public partial class _Default: System.Web.UI.Page
 9 {
10     //..methods and properties
11 }

As you can see, extension is accomplished via the colon (:).

The idea behind a base page is creating a class that extends the System.Web.UI.Page class. Instead of inheriting from the System.Web.UI.Page class, your pages will all inherit from the custom BasePage class.

Creating A BasePage Class

If you haven't already, and since we are working in a "Web Site" project, right click the project name in the solution explorer and follow Add ASP.NET Folder > App_Code.

Right click the new App_Code folder and click "Add New Item". Add a class and name the file BasePage.cs.

Extending The System.Web.UI.Page Class

The idea here is to have our BasePage extend System.Web.UI.Page so that our pages don't have to. We will start out with nothing and build on it as we need to share more functionality. For now take a look at how this extension is accomplished:

1 using System;
2 using System.Web;
3 public class BasePage : System.Web.UI.Page
4 {
5     public BasePage()
6     {
7     }
8 }

Voila! Our BasePage is created. For now we just have an empty constructor, but we will build on this. Our pages can now inherit from this instead of the typical System.Web.UI.Page class.

Creating a Consistent Layout With Master Pages

If you want to create a consistent layout for your web forms, then you will definitely need a master page or two. You can place site wide styles and controls in these bad boys.

Master pages are a lot like aspx pages in that they can contain server controls and they also have their own code-behind file. The key player in a master page is the ContentPlaceHolder control. This guy does exactly what it's name implies; it acts as a placeholder for content. I created a directory in the solution called "MasterPages" to place my master pages. Here is the master page "Layout.master" that will be used for the remainder:

 1 <%@ Master Language="C#" EnableViewState="true" ViewStateMode="Disabled" AutoEventWireup="true" CodeFile="Layout.master.cs" Inherits="MasterPages_Layout" %>
 2 
 3 <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">
 4 
 5 <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
 6 <head runat="server">
 7     <title></title>
 8     <asp:ContentPlaceHolder id="head" runat="server">
 9     </asp:ContentPlaceHolder>
10     <link href="../styles.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" />
11 </head>
12 <body>
13     <form id="form1" runat="server">
14     <div id="topHat" class="add-bottom">
15         <div class="wrapper clearfix">
16             <div class="alignleft">
17                 <a href="Default.aspx">Home</a>
18             </div>
19             <div class="alignright">
20                 <asp:Label AssociatedControlID="ddlThemes" ID="lblThemes" runat="server" EnableTheming="false" Text="Choose Theme: "></asp:Label>
21                 <asp:DropDownList ID="ddlThemes" runat="server" AutoPostBack="true" 
22                     onselectedindexchanged="ddlThemes_SelectedIndexChanged" ViewStateMode="Enabled" EnableTheming="false">
23                     <asp:ListItem>Grid</asp:ListItem>
24                     <asp:ListItem>Midnight</asp:ListItem>
25                 </asp:DropDownList>
26             </div>
27         </div>
28     </div>
29     <div class="wrapper">
30         <asp:ContentPlaceHolder id="ContentForLayout" runat="server">
31         
32         </asp:ContentPlaceHolder>
33     </div>
34     </form>
35 </body>
36 </html>

As you can see, things look pretty similar to a web form. You will notice that instead of the <@Page> directive, there is a <@Master> directive.

Using Master Pages In Web Forms

It is super easy to use a master page in web forms. In the Default.aspx file , you just need to reference the Master Page via the MasterPageFile property of the <@ Page > directive. If your web form is in the root of your web site, and the master page is in the MasterPages directory, the directive will look like the following:

1 <%@ Page Language="C#" MasterPageFile="~/MasterPages/Layout.master" AutoEventWireup="true" CodeFile="Default.aspx.cs" Inherits="_Default" %>

The next step is to make sure that the content from your web form ends up in the placeholder of the master page. This is accomplished with the Content control. Simply wrap the content of your web form in the .aspx file in this control:

1 <asp:Content runat="server" ContentPlaceHolderID="ContentForLayout">
2     <!-- web form content here -->
3 </asp:Content>

The thing to notice here is that the Content control has a property called ContentPlaceHolderID that refers to the ID property of our master page's ContentPlaceHolder control. This is how the ASP.NET run time knows to place the web form's content inside the master page.

Creating a Consistent Look With Themes

We have consistent functionality, consistent layout, and now we need a way to have a consistent style for our application. This is accomplished with Themes. Much like adding the App_Code directory, if you don't have an App_Theme folder already, right click the project name in the solution explorer and follow Add ASP.NET Folder > Theme.

Name your theme what ever you want. I did this twice and created two different themes, one called "Midnight" and one called "Grid"

Theme CSS

After creating a theme, you should add the necessary style sheet(s) to the theme folder (right click > Add New Item > Style Sheet). It is good practice to name the style sheet after the theme, so if my theme is called "Grid", then I should add a style sheet named Grid.css. It is also a good idea to add an images folder for your style sheet to reference if it makes use of background images.

Skins

Another key component of themes is the skin. Skins are files that end in the .skin extension and they are used to "skin" or style controls types in your project. If we want to add a CssClass to every button in our project and style it accordingly in the theme style sheet we would "right click Add New Item" a skin file, and name it something appropriate - say Button.skin. In the skin file we place the control to skin in a web form or master page - much like we would in a web form - only we leave out the ID property.

1 <asp:Button runat="server" CssClass="pizza-button" />

There are more properties you can add in the skin file, but the CssClass property is the most useful as far as consistent aesthetics go for a type of control. Essentially any property supported by skins that is added to this skin file, will be reflected in all the Button controls that show up in your application.

After adding a style sheet, an images directory , and a few skins to my "Grid" theme, my directory structure resembles the following:

Making a Theme Switcher

Let's put this all together to make a global theme switcher. I have created two themes for my application, one called "Grid" and the other called "Midnight". I want to create a simple way for users to select their preferred theme, and have that theme be selected on their next visit. We are going to combine what we know about base pages, master pages, and themes to accomplish this task.

Adding The Theme Drop Down

The first thing we need to do is add a way for our users to select their theme. The best candidate for the job is a DropDownList control. Since this DropDownList needs to be available on every page, we will add this control to our master page. Right under the opening form tag in our master page, we will add this control with some attributes for the CSS and a couple of control properties. I will add ListItem controls for the two available themes.

 1 <div id="topHat" class="add-bottom">
 2     <div class="wrapper clearfix">
 3         <div class="alignleft">
 4             <a href="Default.aspx">Home</a>
 5         </div>
 6         <div class="alignright">
 7             <asp:Label AssociatedControlID="ddlThemes" ID="lblThemes" runat="server" EnableTheming="false" Text="Choose Theme: "></asp:Label>
 8             <asp:DropDownList ID="ddlThemes" runat="server" AutoPostBack="true" 
 9                 onselectedindexchanged="ddlThemes_SelectedIndexChanged" ViewStateMode="Enabled" EnableTheming="false">
10                 <asp:ListItem>Grid</asp:ListItem>
11                 <asp:ListItem>Midnight</asp:ListItem>
12             </asp:DropDownList>
13         </div>
14     </div>
15 </div>

Notice the properties used in our two controls. The Label and the DropDownList both have a property EnableThemeing set to false. Since these are controls that will be present on all pages, we don't want the theme to control how they look.

The DropDownList sets the AutoPostBack property to true in order to wire up a little JavaScript that will submit the form automatically when the value changes.

If you look at the <%@Master> directive in our master page, you will see that by default we disable view state. This is a performance consideration, but we do want our theme switcher to track it's state, so we set the DropDownList property ViewStateMode to true.

I use the global style sheet (styles.css) that I added to the head element of the master page to style this top section, and this is what I end up with:

Handling The Drop Down Event

Remember we set the AutoPostBack property to true, so whenever the value of our control changes, we need some code to handle that event. Since master pages have code-behinds of their own, this is the place to do it. Notice our DropDownList control has an onselectedindexchanged property set to the method ddlThemes_SelectedIndexChanged. We head to the "Layout.master.cs" file and add the following method:

 1 protected void ddlThemes_SelectedIndexChanged(object sender, EventArgs e)
 2 {
 3     HttpCookie userTheme = new HttpCookie("UserTheme")
 4     {
 5         Expires = DateTime.Now.AddMonths(3),
 6         Value = ddlThemes.SelectedValue
 7     };
 8     Response.Cookies.Add(userTheme);
 9     Response.Redirect(Request.Url.ToString());
10 }

The purpose of this method is to take the selected value from the themes list and store it in a cookie. As you can see this cookie is set to expire in 3 months. After the cookie has been added to the Response.Cookies collection, we redirect the user to the URL where the post happened (this will server the purpose of "refreshing" the theme).

In addition to this method that handles the DropDownList changing values, it would be nice to make sure the control is loaded with the correct theme already selected in the control. We will do this on every page when it loads with the Load event. This is as easy adding some logic to the Page_Load method.

 1 protected void Page_Load(object sender, EventArgs e)
 2 {
 3     if (!Page.IsPostBack)
 4     {
 5         string selectedTheme = Page.Theme;
 6         HttpCookie userTheme = Request.Cookies.Get("UserTheme");
 7         if (userTheme != null)
 8         {
 9             selectedTheme = userTheme.Value;
10         }
11         if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(selectedTheme) && ddlThemes.Items.FindByValue(selectedTheme) != null)
12         {
13             ddlThemes.Items.FindByValue(selectedTheme).Selected = true;
14         }
15     }
16 }

First we make sure the page load does not come after a POST request. We use the default theme set for our pages (set in the web.config specifically) as our initial value for the selected theme. We then check to see if a cookie exists for the user's preferred theme, and if it does we make sure there is a corresponding value in the DropDownList. If everything checks out, the DropDownList will have the user's preferred theme already selected in the DropDownList control.

Using The Base Page To Display The Theme

We need to make sure the theme is loaded on every page. The best way to do this is through our BasePage class we created earlier. We will define some methods and make sure they get added as event handlers to every page that inherits from BasePage. Let's open BasePage.cs and get to work.

Loading The Selected Theme

Every page needs to load the theme that has been selected. Themes need to be set early in the ASP.NET page life cycle. The place to do it is the PreInit event. We need to define a method that will check the cookie we set in our master page code-behind and set the current page theme to that selected theme if it exists.

 1 private void Page_PreInit(object sender, EventArgs e)
 2 {
 3     HttpCookie userTheme = Request.Cookies.Get("UserTheme");
 4     if (userTheme != null)
 5     {
 6         string themePath = Request.PhysicalApplicationPath + "App_Themes" + '\\' + userTheme.Value;
 7         if (Directory.Exists(themePath))
 8         {
 9             Page.Theme = userTheme.Value;
10         }
11     }
12 }

First we see if the cookie exists. If it does we use a little System.IO to verify that the theme directory exists. If it does we set the Page.Theme property to the selected theme.

We wire up the event in our BasePage constructor.

1 public BasePage()
2 {
3     //append our Page_PreInit method to the list of handlers
4     this.PreInit += new EventHandler(Page_PreInit);
5 }

Loading Google Web Fonts

I wanted to use some Google Web Fonts in my application, so I have opted to do it in the BasePage class depending on the current theme. This is done during the Load of the page.

 1 private void Page_Load(object sender, EventArgs e)
 2 {
 3     //the theme was set before this in PreInit
 4     string selectedTheme = Page.Theme;
 5     if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(selectedTheme))
 6     {
 7         switch (selectedTheme)
 8         {
 9             case "Grid":
10                 AddStyleSheet("http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Droid+Sans|Lobster");
11                 break;
12             case "Midnight":
13                 AddStyleSheet("http://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Open+Sans|Oswald");
14                 break;
15         }
16     }
17 }

AddStyleSheet is a helper method used to dynamically add style sheets to the Header object.

1 private void AddStyleSheet(string href)
2 {
3     HtmlLink link = new HtmlLink();
4     link.Attributes.Add("rel", "stylesheet");
5     link.Attributes.Add("media", "all");
6     link.Attributes.Add("href", href);
7     link.Attributes.Add("type", "text/css");
8     Header.Controls.Add(link);
9 }

As with our Page_PreInit method, we need to add our Page_Load method to the list of Load event handlers. This is done in the constructor as well.

1 public BasePage()
2 {
3     this.Load += new EventHandler(Page_Load);
4     this.PreInit += new EventHandler(Page_PreInit);
5 }

Extending The Base Page

To make sure our pages are taking advantage of this functionality, we need to make sure the code-behind class is extending our BasePage instead of System.Web.UI.Page 

 1 using System;
 2 using System.Collections.Generic;
 3 using System.Linq;
 4 using System.Web;
 5 using System.Web.UI;
 6 using System.Web.UI.WebControls;
 7 
 8 public partial class _Default : BasePage
 9 {
10     //page code
11 }

Voila!

Our theme switcher is now complete. We can now switch between our two themes with ease!

Don't forget to download the source!

Download Source

entry.title: Processing Web Forms With C#
entry.content:
An Introduction to C#

I couldn't possibly hope to cover all that C# has to offer in one post. I am going to go over some of the things that are visible from the code behind pasted at the end of my last entry.

Lets take a look at the source code one more time:

 1 using System;
 2 using System.Collections.Generic;
 3 using System.Linq;
 4 using System.Web;
 5 using System.Web.UI;
 6 using System.Web.UI.WebControls;
 7 
 8 public partial class _Default : System.Web.UI.Page
 9 {
10     protected void Page_Load(object sender, EventArgs e)
11     {
12         
13     }
14 
15     protected void btnSubmit_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
16     {
17         pnlForm.Visible = false;
18         litName.Text = txtName.Text;
19         litSnack.Text = ddlSnack.SelectedItem.Value;
20         List<String> toppings = lbToppings.Items.Cast<ListItem>().Where(s => s.Selected).Select(s => s.Value).ToList();
21         litToppings.Text = string.Join(", ", toppings.ToArray());
22         if (toppings.Count.Equals(0))
23         {
24             litToppings.Text = "Plain is fine for me";
25         }
26         List<String> seasonings = cblSeasoning.Items.Cast<ListItem>().Where(c => c.Selected).Select(c => c.Value).ToList();
27         litSeasoning.Text = string.Join(", ", seasonings.ToArray());
28         if (seasonings.Count.Equals(0))
29         {
30             litSeasoning.Text = "nothing";
31         }
32         litPisan.Text = rblPisan.SelectedValue;
33         pnlMessage.Visible = true;
34     }
35 }

You may notice some things next to method parameters and in our List objects that you may not be accustomed to in a language like PHP:

1 protected void btnSubmit_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
2 {
3     //event handling code
4 }
5 
6 //OR
7 List<string> seasonings = "....";

I am talking about words like void, object, EventArgs, and string. These are all types (and in the case of void, the lack of one), and they give an important clue to the nature of C#. C# is a strongly typed language. Variables must declare a type (if you are familiar with the dynamic run time available in C#, then get outta here), and methods must declare what type they return.

C# Types

Using types is pretty simple. Before declaring a variable or instantiating an object, you need to declare the type.

1 int count = 0;
2 sbyte age = 25;
3 string name = "Brian";
4 List<string> names = new List<string>();

When you create a method that returns a value, you need to specify what that value is:

1 protected double Add(double a, double b)
2 {
3     return a + b;
4 }

For a full reference of the available types in C#, head on over to the MSDN page on the subject.

Most types can be used for arrays as well.

1 //notice the use of the brackets [] to denote an array
2 string[] names = new string[4];
3 int[] counts = new int[3];

Languages like PHP don't use fixed length arrays, you can add and subtract as many elements as you want. If you try to add too many elements to a C# array you will get an IndexOutOfRangeException error thrown.

To get past this limitation, C# offers the ArrayList. The ArrayList shrinks and stretches on demand. You can easily add objects via the Add method.

1 ArrayList al = new ArrayList();
2 al.Add(0);
3 al.Add(1);
4 al.Add(2);

The problem presented by the ArrayList is that it does not care what types you add to it. If you are expecting a collection of int objects and a string object gets added on accident, you could be in trouble.

Enter Generics

To get past this, C# introduces something called generics. Generics are basically templates that can be used for a specific type. You saw one used above. The List object specifies that it is a collection of string objects, and it works just like the ArrayList in that it can grow and shrink on demand.

1 //list of strings
2 List<string> strings = new List<string>();
3 strings.Add("string1");
4 strings.Add("string2");
5 
6 //list of ints
7 List<int> ints = new List<int>();
8 ints.Add(1);
9 ints.Add(2);

Using C# to Handle ASP.NET Events

There are plenty of other things to cover when it comes to C#, things like classes, methods, and properties to name a few. There is just too much to cover in this short post, so I am going to stick to the plan of covering what is apparent in the code-behind for the "Pizza Greeter".

Let's use what we have learned so far to understand the btnSubmit_Click event being used. The btnSubmit_Click event is executed as a method of the _Default class. We tell our web form to run this method when the button is clicked via the OnClick property of the Button control.

1 <asp:Button ID="btnSubmit" Text="submit" runat="server" OnClick="btnSubmit_Click" />

When the Button is clicked , our event handles the form submission.

1 protected void btnSubmit_Click(object sender, EventArgs e)
2 {
3     //event code here
4 }

Accessing Controls

Remember we ID controls in our web forms. We can access our controls by their IDs in C#. So the first thing we do is hide our form and set some values.

1 //hide the form panel
2 pnlForm.Visible = false;
3 //set the Name Literal's text to the value of the Name TextBox
4 litName.Text = txtName.Text;
5 //set the Snack Literal's text to the value of the Snack DropDownList's selected item
6 litSnack.Text = ddlSnack.SelectedItem.Value;

Using LINQ to Get Selected Items

List type controls can have a SelectionMode property set to "Multiple" to allow multiple items to be selected. Normally you would have to loop through the control's Items property and see which items have a Selected property that is true. To save ourselves the hassle of looping, we will use LINQ to return a list of the items that are selected.

 1 //cast the list items to a generic of type ListItem and then run some LINQ magic
 2 List<string> toppings = lbToppings.Items.Cast<ListItem>().Where(s => s.Selected).Select(s => s.Value).ToList();
 3 //join the returned list with commas
 4 litToppings.Text = string.Join(", ", toppings.ToArray());
 5 //if the linq expression returns an empty set, then no topping were selected
 6 if (toppings.Count.Equals(0))
 7 {
 8     //set the text of the toppings Literal to a message indicating you don't need any toppings
 9     litToppings.Text = "Plain is fine for me";
10 }

For more on Linq, check these samples on the MSDN out.

The rest of the event code is similar to the first part. We will set some more Literal controls and use a similar LINQ expression to get more selected items.

 1 List<String> seasonings = cblSeasoning.Items.Cast<ListItem>().Where(c => c.Selected).Select(c => c.Value).ToList();
 2 litSeasoning.Text = string.Join(", ", seasonings.ToArray());
 3 if (seasonings.Count.Equals(0))
 4 {
 5     litSeasoning.Text = "nothing";
 6 }
 7 //get the selected item from the RadioButtonList and set the Pisan Literal Text property to it's value
 8 litPisan.Text = rblPisan.SelectedValue;
 9 //finally show the message Panel - effectively swapping the form Panel with the message Panel
10 pnlMessage.Visible = true;

Before the form is submitted:

After the form is submitted:

C# is an incredibly powerful language, and as we proceed into more complex applications, there will only be more powerful features to explore.

entry.title: An Introduction To ASP.NET Server Controls
entry.content:
Server controls are at the heart of ASP.NET web form applications. Server controls build up the user interface and enable you to gather user input, update certain parts of your application in response to that input, and keep state between web requests. You can also bind data sources to them in order to interact with something like a SQL database.

An Introduction To Server Controls

As you can see there are quite a few server controls to choose from. I am not going to go in to detail about all of these, but they all have some common ground. I am going to focus mainly on the standard controls at this point in the game, and we will use some of the standard controls in today's example.

Common Control Properties

runat

This is always set to the value of server. This property makes your control and all of it's properties available to your code-behind and indicates the control should be processed by the server.

1 <asp:TextBox ID="txtName" runat="server" />

ID

This property uniquely identifies the control and is used to access the control from the code-behind. If we use the same TextBox control used above, we would access it's Text property from our C# file like so:

1 txtName.Text

Visible

This property is handy for controls that need to be revealed in response to something. This property is not like display:none in CSS. If the Visible property is set to true, the control will never be sent to the browser in the first place. The following panel control will never be sent to the browser unless told to do so in a code-behind:

1 <asp:Panel ID="pnlMessage" runat="server" Visible="false">
2 </asp:Panel>

ViewStateMode

This property is a handy property that enables you to control the view state on a control by control basis.

The "View State Engine" is something that controls the state of controls (what text/option/value is selected in a control) across requests (think sticky forms on steroids).

The ViewStateMode property is something that allows you to fine tune this behavior for the sake of performance. For more information on view state in ASP.NET check out this page on MSDN.

AutoPostBack

This property makes sense on the controls that actually collect user input. This uses a little client side magic to ensure that when this control has finished gathering input, it is time to submit the form. Completing the input will automatically cause a post back to the server.

Standard Properties

In addition to the runat and ID attributes there are several attributes that map to standard HTML attributes. ToolTip essentially works as an HTML title attribute, CssClass maps to the HTML class attribute, and there are a bunch of inline style properties like BackColor and ForeColor. I would rather see CssClass and a style sheet used to handle styles rather than the built in style properties.

There are more properties available and your best bet to seeing them all in action is to fire up Visual Web Developer and explore what is available.

Server Controls In Action

Let's make a simple application using some server controls and a little C# in our code-behind. We are going to modify our previous example from the last two entries in this series to see what kind of pizza the user prefers.

Collecting Input With the TextBox Control

The first thing we are going to do is add a list to our wrapper to hold our form controls and then add our inputs:

1 <form id="form1" runat="server">
2 <div id="wrapper">
3     <h1>Web Forms Are Gnarly</h1>
4     <dl>
5     </dl>
6 </div>
7 </form>

Now that we have our list setup, we can start adding controls to it. We need to add inputs and label elements for each one. Let's start with a way to collect text input:

1 <dl>
2     <dt><asp:Label ID="lblName" runat="server" Text="What's your name?" AssociatedControlID="txtName" /></dt>
3     <dd><asp:TextBox ID="txtName" runat="server" /></dd>
4 </dl>

You'll notice a couple of things:

First each of our controls contain the runat property. This is mandatory for server controls.

The Text property on our label specifies what will be read within the label.

Each control has an ID property so they can be identified in the C# file. Take note of the AssociatedControlID property that exists on the Label control. This essentially functions like the HTML for attribute that exists on HTML label elements. Notice the value of this property is the ID property of the associated control, in this case txtName.

A Note On Naming Conventions

Everyone has their own way of ID'ing controls, but a popular convention is to shorthand the type of control and then follow it with your name for it. Our TextBox control is used to collect a name, so we ID it as txtName

Selecting From a List With List Controls

The next control to add to our list is the drop down list. This is your typical select element. All list controls follow a similar pattern of:

1 <asp:ListType ID="listID" runat="server">
2     <asp:ListItem Value="1">Label1</asp:ListItem>

Grouping Related Items With Container Controls

entry.title: C#: What Is Boxing?
entry.content:
I was recently asked to explain what boxing in C# is. Well I couldn't give an answer on the spot so here I am reporting my findings. It is a pretty simple concept, and one that is probably used a lot without realizing it. According to MSDN: "The concept of boxing and unboxing underlies the C# unified view of the type system, in which a value of any type can be treated as an object."

Boxing Is Implicit

This really looks like assigning a value object to a System.Object. This shows int i being boxed and assigned to an object:

1 int i = 123;
2 object o = i;

Unboxing Is Explicit

This is essentially type casting.

Here we have the object o assigned our value object. We "unbox" our System.Object and assign it to our int 

1 o = 123;
2 i = (int)o;

What Is The Big Deal?

This has a lot of application that can creep up (basically anytime you may need to treat one value type as another), but to me it seems to have its greatest application in collections of mixed objects.

 1 List<object> mixedList = new List<object>();
 2 mixedList.Add("String");
 3 for (int j = 5; j < 10; j++)
 4 {
 5     mixedList.Add(j);
 6 }
 7 
 8 //use C#'s dynamic powers to iterate. we use the keyword 'var' below so that the compiler gets to decided the type
 9 for (var item in mixedList)
10 {
11     Console.WriteLine(item);
12 }

This is pretty transparent in a dynamic language where types are used freely all the time (i.e "5" + 5 = 10). C# enables this same kind of juggling with it's concept of boxing.

One final note:

Our friends at Microsoft have this little tidbit to say about boxing and its performance implications:

In relation to simple assignments, boxing and unboxing are computationally expensive processes. When a value type is boxed, a new object must be allocated and constructed. To a lesser degree, the cast required for unboxing is also expensive computationally.

Now move forward confidently, knowing you can answer the question: "What is boxing?".

entry.title: My Admiration Of C# Object Initializers
entry.content:
I had to ponder... what are some things I like about C#?

Well there are some obvious answers like generics, a comprehensive framework class library, delegates, dynamic typing, so on and so on.

One thing that came to mind as I thought about it is something day to day C# coders love but seldom give a second thought to: object initializers. The means for doing this in C# is pretty cool, and me being someone who has his foot in a lot of different environments and languages - I can really appreciate how cool this convention is.

The C# object initializer syntax is most useful when you have a need to create an object and alter it's state after instantiation, usually to affect the outcome of some behavior. The alternative is creating an object that creates it's state based on what is passed to the constructor.

Let's take a look at a common task, let's say sending email via SMTP, in PHP and then C# using the object initializer syntax.

Initializing Objects The PHP Way

Let's first look at the PHPMailer class. This is a pretty typical scenario in the land of PHP.

 1 <?php
 2 require_once 'PHPMailer5/class.phpmailer.php';
 3 
 4 $mail = new PHPMailer();
 5 $mail->IsSMTP(); 
 6 $mail->Host = 'smtp.server.com';
 7 $mail->Port = 25;
 8 $mail->SMTPAuth = true;
 9 $mail->Username = 'user';
10 $mail->Password = 'password';
11 $mail->SetFrom('brian@brianscaturro.com', 'Brian');
12 $mail->AddAddress('bill@email.me', 'Bill');
13 $mail->Subject = 'How are you?';
14 $mail->Body = 'This e-mail was sent using PHPMailer.';
15 $mail->Send();

We create our new object, and proceed to set one property after another on the $mail instance of our PHPMailer class. It is functional, and it is pretty straightforward as to what we are doing.

The downside is there is a lot of redundancy as we have to always operate on the already instantiated $mail object. $mail->this,$mail->that,$mail->something_else.

Initializing Objects The C# Way

The .NET framework comes with a lot of handy tools built right in. This set of tools is called the framework class library or FCL. This is a huge bonus for the .NET environment.

In languages like PHP, there are plenty of great tools, but you have to do quite a bit of hunting to find one that suits your needs, store it in the file system, and then require them into your script.

The equivalent (and let's face it, easier) way of including our built-in .NET email classes is to use the using directive at the top of our C# file:

1 using System.Net.Mail

Let's look at simple example of using the .NET MailMessage class with the handy object initializer syntax to send our email over SMTP:

 1 MailMessage email = new MailMessage()
 2 {
 3     Subject = "How are you?",
 4     Body = "This e-mail was sent using .NET",
 5     IsBodyHtml = false,
 6     From = new MailAddress("brian@brianscaturro.com","Brian")
 7 };
 8 email.To.Add(new MailAddress("bill@email.me", "Bill"));
 9 
10 SmtpClient server = new SmtpClient();
11 server.Send(email);

Server,port, and authentication details are stored in the convenient Web.config file that .NET uses, and are passed to our SmtpClient class transparently. Look at all the redundancy that we removed! You can see that rather than typing email.Subject,email.Body, email.blah, we can do new Class() { //properties }.

This is also a gem for collections in C#:

1 List<Cat> cats = new List<Cat>;
2 { 
3     new Cat(){Name = "Whiskers"},
4     new Cat(){Name = "Boots"} 
5 }

Very cool stuff.

.NET is an awesome framework, that has a lot of great tools to simplify the work at hand. Object initializers are probably so widely used that the C# community might take them for granted, but when you stack them against some of the alternative ways other languages do things - you can really appreciate this useful convention.

entry.title: Normalize.css - My new reset
entry.content:
Just a short little tidbit on something I have been digging lately. Many of us who work with CSS on a daily basis have some kind of reset mechanism built in. There are a bunch of options out there these days, but for many the timeless classic is Eric Meyer's CSS reset. Another popular offering in today's HTML5 wilds is the HTML5 doctor HTML5 CSS reset.

Is All That Really Necessary?

We use these resets to bring every browser to a common ground. Wipe out padding, margin, font-size variations, and the like. We forget that browsers have some defaults that can be handy. Margin on block elements can be very helpful. Why change something you don't need to.

Another useful convention implemented by most browsers are greater size/weight given to header tags, and this is usually desired.

Enter normalize.css

Why not get the best of both worlds? I have been using this bad motha in projects lately, and I am pleased with what I see. According to the normalize.css site normalize does the following:

  • Preserves useful defaults, unlike many CSS resets
  • Normalizes styles for a wide range of elements
  • Corrects bugs and common browser inconsistencies.
  • Improves usability with subtle improvements
  • Explains what code does using detailed comments.

You get a lot of bonuses you might otherwise take for granted. Things like audio elements without controls (which are useless) being hidden, maintaining consistent font size with ems, cake sure pre-formatted text is readable, consistent sup and sub elements, image quality when scaling in IE, and a tone more.

Give it a look-see!

entry.title: CakePHP - Unit Testing Models
entry.content:
Testing is critical to any application development process. Seeing that green bar instills confidence to move forward, and gives you a handy tool to ensure any future changes won't break your carefully crafted application.

CakePHP is one of the big kids on the block for rapid development in the PHP community, and it comes with some nice tools for testing your MVC applications. We are going to take a look at testing the M in that acronym. Let's cover setting up fixtures and test cases to automate this process.

Setup CakePHP for testing

CakePHP 1.3 uses the popular PHP testing framework SimpleTest. CakePHP is compatible with the 1.0.x branch of SimpleTest, and making CakePHP ready for testing is as easy as dropping the simpletest folder into the app/vendor directory. From here out we will be working in the app/tests directories of our CakePHP installation.

Creating test fixtures

Fixtures are a way to get temporary test data into your test cases. They are always a good idea because they isolate your test data from your live data. CakePHP uses fixtures to create test tables, populate those tables, then delete those tables all in the course of running a test. Fixtures are also handy because they spare you the task of creating and deleting data manually.

We are going to be testing a typical user class in CakePHP and we will begin by creating a fixture for the User model. Create our fixture file in app/tests/fixtures and name it user_fixture.php. Creating a fixture is easy:

1 <?php
2 class UserFixture extends CakeTestFixture {
3     var $name = 'User';
4 }

Notice the $name property. This should be the same thing you would use for the $name property in the User model we are testing. The next thing we need to do is setup the $fields property. This property is used to mirror the schema for the model.

 1 <?php
 2 class UserFixture extends CakeTestFixture {
 3     var $name = 'User';
 4 
 5     var $fields = array(
 6         'id' => array('type' => 'integer','key' => 'primary'),
 7 	'username' => array('type' => 'string','length' => 100, 'null' => false),
 8 	'password' => array('type' => 'string','length' => 40, 'null' => false),
 9 	'email' => array('type' => 'string','length' => 255, 'null' => false),
10 	'cdate' => array('type' => 'timestamp','null' => true,'default' => null)
11     );
12 }

Each key of the $fields property represents a property of the model (or column in the database ). For each property you pass an array with information about the property. The keys available to that array are the following:

typeAn internal CakePHP data type. The following map to the equivalent SQL types: string (VARCHAR), text (TEXT), integer (INT), float (FLOAT), datetime (DATETIME), timestamp (TIMESTAMP), time (TIME), date (DATE), binary (BLOB)

keyIdentifies the field as the primary key and sets it to auto increment.

lengthThe length the field should take.

nullTrue to allow nulls, false to disallow nulls.

defaultThe default value for the field.

Our $fields property above uses these fields to mirror the schema that is in our database for the User model. The final step is to populate our fixtures with some data, and this is done with the $records property. Place it right below the $fields property:

1 <?php
2 var $records = array(
3     array('id' => 1,'username' => 'bscaturro','email' => 'scaturrob@gmail.com','password' => 'a94a8fe5ccb19ba61c4c0873d391e987982fbbd3','cdate' => '2011-11-16 06:59:22')
4 );

Alternatively you can use the $import property to import live data from the model:

1 <?php
2 $import = 'User';

Using CakePHP Test Fixtures

Since we are testing our User model, we will create our test in app/tests/cases/models. Call the file user.test.php and set it up like so:

 1 <?php
 2 App::import('Model','User');
 3 class UserTestCase extends CakeTestCase {
 4 	
 5 	var $fixtures = array('app.user');
 6 
 7 	function startCase() {
 8 		$this->User = ClassRegistry::init('User');
 9 	}
10 
11 	function endCase() {
12 		ClassRegistry::flush();
13 	}
14 }

Note that we are using App::import at the top to include our model.

The $fixtures property is how we utilize the fixture we created above. The $fixtures property takes an array of fixture names, each one prefixed with one of three values. These three values can be app, plugin, or core. You can probably take a stab at what these mean, but I will clarify just in case.

The app prefix means our fixture represents an application model, something from our own application like our User model.

The plugin prefix allows you to specify that it is a fixture for a plugin model and it uses a dot syntax to specify the plugin, something like plugin.myplugin.pizza.

The core prefix signals it is a fixture for the core files that come with CakePHP.

Our startCase method fires when the test case starts and within it we use the ClassRegistry class to initialize a User model as a property of the test case. The endCase method is used to flush the ClassRegistry of our initialized class at the very end of the test case.

Something to note, if your User model has relationships, like hasMany, you will need to include fixtures for those as well, even if you are not using them. So if a User model is using the $hasMany property to include Publication models, then you would need to create a PublicationFixture in app/tests/fixtures and the $fixtures property of UserTestCase would have to be updated to look like the following:

1 <?php
2 var $fixtures = array('app.user','app.publication');

Writing Test Methods To Test The User model

Our UserTestCase class is the spot to place our test methods. We will focus on testing weather or not our model validations are working. So let's look at our class definition for the User model to see what exactly we are testing:

 1 <?php
 2 class User extends AppModel {
 3 	var $name = 'User';
 4 
 5 	var $validate = array(
 6 		'username' => array(
 7 			'rule' => 'notEmpty',
 8 			'message' => 'Username must not be empty',
 9 			'required' => true
10 		),
11 		'password' => array(
12 			'rule' => 'matchesConf',
13 			'message' => "Passwords don't match",
14 			'required' => true
15 		),
16 		'email' => array(
17 			'unique' => array(
18 				'rule' => 'isUnique',
19 				'message' => 'Email is already taken',
20 				'required' => true
21 			),
22 			'email' => array(
23 				'rule' => 'email',
24 				'message' => 'Not a valid email address'
25 			)
26 		)
27 	);
28 
29 	var $hasMany = array(
30 		'Publication' => array(
31 			'foreignKey' => 'user_id',
32 			'dependent' => true
33 		)
34 	);
35 
36 	function matchesConf($check) {
37 		if (! empty($this->data['User']['passConf']) ) {
38 			return $check['password'] == $this->data['User']['passConf'];
39 		}
40 		return false;
41 	}
42 }

As you can see we have a unique validation rule on the email field in our User model validations. Seeing how Cake does a database look up of this field to see if it is unique or not, we better have some test data to use in the database. Fixtures to the rescue!

The data we created in the $records property of our fixture will be used as our source of data to test against! So we can write our test to see if this validation is truly working. We simply write a test that attempts to create a user with the same email as the user we created in the $records property of UserFixture. We want to verify that validation fails:

 1 <?php
 2 function testUserEmailMustBeUnique() {
 3 	$this->User->create(array(
 4 		'username' => 'bscaturro',
 5 		'email' => 'scaturrob@gmail.com',
 6 		'password' => 'pass',
 7 		'passConf' => 'pass',
 8 		'cdate' => null
 9 	));
10         //make sure it doesn't pass validation!
11 	$this->assertFalse($this->User->validates());
12 }

The above method of UserTestCase gives a couple of hints about testing conventions. The first thing you should note is that all test methods must begin with the word test. This is how the test runner knows to run the method as a test.

The last thing we do in a test method is run an assertion. Here we assert that the validation is false. For a complete list of assertions available, check out the SimpleTest site.

Keep writing those test methods until you are certain all of your validations and model methods are passing. If you really want to go nuts, try writing your tests before you write your actual model code. There is no need to do any cleanup (deleting test records) when you are done. Our fixtures will take care of their own cleanup.

Running CakePHP Tests

All tests are run from the test.php file that exists in the web root. If my application is installed at dev.myapp.com then the test runner is located at dev.myapp.com/test.php. Visit this URL and you are given a list of possible tests to run. We will be running the "Test Cases" from the App heading:

From there you will click the models/User link and see the following beacon of hope!

Conclusion

There are a couple of other useful methods like startTest and endTest that are run at the start and end of each test method. They are passed the method being run so you can utilize them like so:

1 <?php
2 function startTest($method) {
3     if ( $method == 'testUserEmailMustBeUnique' ) {
4         //do stuff for this specific test
5     }
6 }

Keep experimenting and perfecting your testing process! CakePHP provides some awesome tools for automating testing. Be sure to download the complete files used in this introduction to testing models in CakePHP.
